fields.description:
As a developer I can configure my plan to show links to external tools in the results of a build or a deployment so that I can easily get to related information in those tools.

For example: The Freezer plan template can publish a link to the Manifesto deployment dashboard for a plugin promote done when deploying to an environment in a deployment project. This saves the developer having to trawl through the deployment log looking for the dashboard URL.
fields.summary: Allow plans to publish links to other tools in build and deploy results

fields.description: The vast majority of Bamboo's API documentation is completely unusable. Very few of the calls have any description of what they do, any additional parameters are usually lacking in description as well, and the "expand" menus (that should contain feedback examples) are nearly always empty. Without ample documentation, it's extremely difficult for me to know what functionality Bamboo's REST API has.
fields.summary: Please, please, PLEASE improve the Bamboo REST API documentation!

fields.description:
When listing the users assigned permissions for a plan any "global administrators" will not be listed - mostly as they will already have the ability to access and run the plan anyway. 

However for some customers, they would like to use this list to indicate which administrators would be the "go to" admins for the plan. 

An good improvement for Bamboo would be that when an global administrator is explicitly added to a plan that they are listed.
fields.summary: List Global administrators when explicitly assigned to a plan

fields.description: As far as I can tell, there's no way to do this, and you can't view the admins of a plan unless you are also an admin of that plan. As a result, our team (we manage bamboo) gets a lot of requests to make changes to plans that the admins of those plans could do just as easily.
fields.summary: Retrieve plan admins via REST API

fields.description: We are heavily utilizing the Docker agent support for Bamboo which has been a very useful feature. However, in many cases it would be great to not having to pre-provision Docker based build agents and have them created on a per-need basis for builds/deployments. After the build/deployment the instance can optionally be terminated. I see this more or less similar to Bamboo's support for EC2 agents which have similar features.
fields.summary: Dynamically provisioned Docker build agents / Elastic Docker

fields.description: Customer requested 1.7 to be listed since it has been released. Currently on 1.6
fields.summary: Add Node.js version 1.7 to list on cloud

fields.description:
I believe currently only those who has Bamboo server admin permission could manage agent capabilities/executables. 

Some times, the Bamboo admin may want to grant an owner of some build plans the ability to manage the capabilities of build agent. So that the owner of the plan would not request the bamboo admin to add capabilities every time. And at the same time the admin may not want to let the owner has the admin privilege to the whole bamboo system.

It might be good to create a new tick box for the permissions to manage agent capabilities.
fields.summary: Add "managing agent capability/executable permissions" as a separate permission option

fields.description:
h3. Problem Description

When an call is passed to Bamboo that may be incorrect or out of date, say for an project element that has been deleted, an less than impressive error page and stack dump is presented to the user, suggesting they contact support.

When reached from another Atlassian App, this can make it look like Bamboo has crashed or halted, where a simple back button would return the use to their last location. While we do include a link to the homesite, its perhaps not as clear as it could be.

h3. Suggested Solution

A better approach may be to have, not only an Atlassian look to the page rather than plain text, but to better utilize the error that was returned to inform the customer to a suitable action. Separating the error out from the dump, and providing clear suggestion as to the next action, which may not even require a call to support to address it.
fields.summary: Better presentation of 400/500 type errors for Bamboo

fields.description:
Though it's mentioned in our documents that "Bamboo is a pure Java application and should run on any platform, provided all the JDK requirements are satisfied.", it will be very helpful to also list all supported and/or unsupported operating systems for better clarity:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Supported+platforms
fields.summary: List unsupported operating systems

fields.description:
According to our documentation [Configuring global expiry|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+global+expiry], you can configure [build expiry for individual build plans|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+build+results+expiry+for+a+plan] to override the global expiry settings. *You can not yet override the global expiry configuration for particular deployment projects*.

Please, extend this feature to deployment projects as well.
fields.summary: Global expiry configuration for particular deployment projects

fields.description:
This case is specific to Stash but could add value for other repo types. 

If Stash is performing a daily backup the server becomes unable to respond to Bamboo. In cases where Stash commits trigger Bamboo, Bamboo's ping test of Stash will fail and it'll revert to polling and in standard polling trigger this applies. If Bamboo attempts to poll Stash while it's backing up Bamboo will throw errors for each repository it attempts to poll. This causes unnecessary error logging during that time.

It would be great if there was a way to disable Bamboo polling for a specific time frame or if the polling was smart enough to know that Stash was backing up (it seems that this would require some Stash changes as well though).
fields.summary: Add the ability to suspend Bamboo polling of a repository

fields.description: In the attached screenshot, the order of the jobs on the left hand side list is case-insensitive ("UAC acceptance tests", "Unit tests", "UPP acceptance tests"). In the "Live activity log" menu, the order is case-sensitive ("UAC acceptance tests", "UPP acceptance tests", "Unit tests").
fields.summary: Inconsistency between case-sensitive and case-insensitive ordering

fields.description: Tomcat 7.x comes with the new feature of [parallel deployment|http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-7.0-doc/config/context.html#Parallel_deployment] where users can deploy multiple versions with same context at same time. While this something that is managed in Tomcat and bamboo is able to do deployments on same context, we are missing some features like versioning the web application.It will be nice to extend this for a better support of this feature
fields.summary: Extend the Bamboo tomcat plugin to properly support parallel deployment

fields.description:
Currently, _Final Task_ would not be ran if the automatic merge fails because the plan would not start at all.

In some configuration, the final task is used to update notification services that is not supported by the current notification schemes.
fields.summary: Run Final Task even if automatic merging fails
TriggerConfigurationService.createTriggerList() empty implementation

fields.description:
Please reference https://support.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer#portal/10/BSP-16751 for more information.  I would like the ability to be able to tag the build in Git after the build has completed successfully.  I haven't been able to find a similar Feature/Enhancement for this but have come across other similar items within Answers that are referenced in the ticket above but specifically here is one - 
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/112416/.  My ultimate goal is to easily be able to compare builds and get the data in a readable format and not specifcally all the commit info.  I have a basic workarond to provide what I need in that I can do a diff on the commit hash from the newest build and compare to the commit from the last build.  This is not very clean and feel this is something that should work right out of the box.  

We are only in evaluation mode at the moment and when comparing build tools against Jenkins etc - this would be something that doesn't score in Bamboo's favor since this is readily available in other tools. Overall I really like most of the options/abilities of Bamboo but there are a couple of things like this that make it more difficult when comparing against other tools in the build area.
fields.summary: Ability to automatically tag your build in GIT from Bamboo

fields.description:
Is it possible for Bamboo to notify JIRA when an issue has been deployed to an environment?

We currently go through the list of issues in the new release(s) being deployed to an environment and manually add comment on each issue.

This feature should provide reasonable value to any customers using JIRA + Bamboo Deployments.

Thanks!

fields.description:
When triggering a rollback users can get exception if the plan definition has changed. For instance here's an example from a customer:

{quote}
In my build plan, I was collecting to sets of artifacts. Let's call them "artfacts1" and "artifacts2". I created a build called "build-1", and these artifacts were archived with that build.

I created a deployment plan, and it referenced both "artifacts1" and "artifacts2". I created a release called "release-1" and deployed them.

Later, I decided to remove "artifacts2" from my build plan because moving forward I don't need them.

Now I realize I need to rollback/redeploy my existing deployment using "release-1". If I try to do this, I get:
"Could not execute 'ENVIRONMENT:6258689': java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Unable to find an artifact definition for name: artifacts2"
{quote}

We should not trigger that exception and should have an appropriate message informing the user that an artifact definition is missing to replay the plan.
fields.summary: Bamboo should display proper error messages if artifact definitions are missing during deployments

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e3f7fc}
(i)   When using Bamboo 5.6+ and Stash 3.2+ newly created *Application Link* with default settings:
* The servers have the same set of users and usernames *disabled*
* I am an administrator on both instances *enabled*\\
\\
will result in application link created with:
* Trusted Apps authentication *disabled*
* OAuth authentication *enabled*:
** Allow 2-Legged OAuth *enabled*
** Allow user impersonation through 2-Legged OAuth *disabled*
* Basic Auth authentication *disabled*

Please, make sure you have "{{Stash administration >> Settings >> Server Settings >> SSH access}}" configured as per following:
{noformat}
[x] SSH enabled
[x] SSH access keys enabled
SSH Port: 7999
{noformat}
{panel}

* When configuring repository definition on Bamboo side (either in "{{Plan configuration >> Repositories"}} tab or in "{{Bamboo administration >> Build resources >> Linked repositories}}") Bamboo will create SSH keypair and will store private key in the repository configuration and upload public key to Stash (_it can be seen in the list of SSH keys of a user X who defined repository on Bamboo side_).
* When running a build Bamboo will present the private key thus making Stash recognise it as user X (_independently on how plan was ran_).

h5. Improvement
Instead of storing public key under the users' account, it would be beneficial storing it under the repository itself, avoiding the necessity of:
# if a user is removed from Stash, it is required to redefine repository settings in Bamboo to new SSH keypair be generated
# easier to manage repository permissions
Please let me know if you have any more questions related to this.
fields.summary: SSH public key be store in repository instead of user's account

fields.description:
When creating a new Plan, under "{{Plan configuration >> Permissions}}" tab the following permission gets created by default:
||Users||View||Edit||Build||Clone||Admin||
|<bamboo-admin>|(/)|(/)|(/)|(/)|(/)|

||Other||View||Edit||Build||Clone||Admin||
|Logged in users|(/)| | | | |
|Anonymous users|(/)| | | | |

It would be interesting if you could set up default permissions to be used when creating a new Plan.

Example, having users under the group *group-a* where they have access to *edit* plans. As a result, when creating a new Plan, the following would be added automatically to the "{{Plan configuration >> Permissions}}" tab:

||Groups||View||Edit||Build||Clone||Admin||
|*group-a*|(/)|(/)| | | |
fields.summary: Set default permissions before creating a new plan(s)

fields.description:
Setting bamboo and stash with nginx proxy with SSL but stash commit trigger not work properly.

nginx setting

location /bamboo {
        proxy_pass          http://127.0.0.1:8101/bamboo;
        proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-Host $host;
        proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-Server $host;
        proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-Proto https;
        port_in_redirect    off;
        proxy_redirect      http://127.0.0.1:8101/bamboo https://dev.mycompany.com/bamboo;
    }

location /stash {
        proxy_pass          http://127.0.0.1:8141/stash;
        proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-Host $host;
        proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-Server $host;
        proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-Proto https;
        port_in_redirect    off;
        proxy_redirect      http://127.0.0.1:8141/stash https://dev.mycompany.com/stash;
    }

stash server.xml

<Connector port="8141" protocol="HTTP/1.1"
                   connectionTimeout="20000"
                   redirectPort="8443"
                   compression="off"
                   compressableMimeType="text/html,text/xml,text/plain,text/css,application/json,application/javascript,application/x-javascript"
                   useBodyEncodingForURI="true"
                   URIEncoding="UTF-8"
                   proxyName="dev.mycompany.com"
                   proxyPort="443"
                   scheme="https"
                   secure="true"
                   />
        <Connector port="8142" protocol="HTTP/1.1"
                   connectionTimeout="20000"
                   redirectPort="8443"
                   compression="off"
                   compressableMimeType="text/html,text/xml,text/plain,text/css,application/json,application/javascript,application/x-javascript"
                   useBodyEncodingForURI="true"
                   URIEncoding="UTF-8"
                   />

bamboo's server.xml

<Connector port="8101"
                   maxThreads="50"
                   minSpareThreads="10"
                   connectionTimeout="20000"
                   enableLookups="false"
                   maxHttpHeaderSize="8192"
                   protocol="HTTP/1.1"
                   redirectPort="8443"
                   acceptCount="100"
                   disableUploadTimeout="true"
                   useBodyEncodingForURI="true"
                   URIEncoding="UTF-8"
                   proxyName="dev.mycompany.com"
                   proxyPort="443"
                   scheme="https"
                   secure="true"
                   />
        <Connector port="8102"
                   maxThreads="50"
                   minSpareThreads="10"
                   connectionTimeout="20000"
                   enableLookups="false"
                   maxHttpHeaderSize="8192"
                   protocol="HTTP/1.1"
                   redirectPort="8443"
                   acceptCount="100"
                   disableUploadTimeout="true"
                   useBodyEncodingForURI="true"
                   URIEncoding="UTF-8"
                   />

Application Link set properly using http not https (because of https Application link behind nginx not work [capability warning]

Also set SSO with crowd.

bamboo trigger with Post-Web Hook is ok, but not work integrated feature.

but restart bamboo, Queued stash commit triggered, and working (Only work restart bamboo server)

P.S : Both same machine.

OS : Mac OS X 10.10 Yosemite

Edit: Trigger without SSL Proxy (Proxy nginx without SSL) work properly, guess OAuth or SSL Proxy is wrong...

Edit 2 : Bamboo to stash Application link changed to ([Bamboo] http <- > [Stash] HTTPS) Work Auto Trigger build but "VERY" Slowly.
It triggered commit after 5-10Min
fields.summary: Bamboo behind nginx proxy with SSL not working stash commit trigger.

fields.description:
{{ChangeView}} is a new field type for Perforce workspaces (introduced in 2014.2). It's defined as:

{noformat}
	ChangeView:  Restricts depot paths to a particular point in time.
	             Example: //depot/path/...@1000
	             Revisions submitted to the path after the specified
	             changelist will not be visible.  Files matching a
	             ChangeView path may not be submitted.
{noformat}

We have a build plan which requires two of the entries in the workspace to be locked at a certain level. (Here, I've used a changelist number, but a label is likely.

We allow Bamboo to manage the workspace because no other option is viable when we have more than one agent. (It's also using the workspace to detect changes because having a workspace with more than one View entry will yield incorrect change detection.)

However, when the Bamboo server manages the agent, it removes the field from the client entirely. Here's the diff from before and after queuing a build using a plan which had the ChangeView block in place:

{code}
% p4 diff2 //Specs/client/bamboo::ps-dev-foo.p4s#4 //Specs/client/bamboo::ps-dev-foo.p4s#5
==== //Specs/client/bamboo::ps-dev-foo.p4s#99 (ctext) - //Specs/client/bamboo::ps-dev-foo.p4s#100 (ctext) ==== content
1c1
< # The form data below was edited by john.doe
---
> # The form data below was edited by bamboo
38c38
< Update:	2014/12/17 10:08:52
---
> Update:	2014/12/17 12:32:29
65,68d64
< 
< ChangeView:
< 	//Products/Reporting/development/Tahoe/...@1021498
< 	//Products/ReportingSDK/development/Tahoe/...@1021498
{code}

Bamboo should leave fields alone if it doesn't understand rather than removing them from scope.
fields.summary: Bamboo Agents remove perforce "ChangeView" entries when bamboo is allowed to manage workspaces

fields.description:
I have found that the Continuous Plugin Deployment plugin's 'Deploy Plugin' task doesn't check the status of a plugin after uploading to confirm that the installation was successful. So the upload may have broken the plugin and the task will return as successful.

As far as I can tell, UPM has endpoints available to check plugin status, should this Condinuous Deployment Plugin be checking them? 

Raising here because this appears to be a Bamboo-owned plugin, sorry if it is not:
{{com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.deploy.continuous-plugin-deployment}}
fields.summary: Continuous Plugin Deployment Plugin doesn't confirm result of plugin deployment

{code}

see Bamboo summary page in attachment

Do we have a solution for this?

fields.description:
Yesterday we've been notified that Bamboo stopped a large number of builds because they were not processed in time on the Bamboo server. 

The pattern normally looked like this:
{noformat}
2014-12-17 14:52:02,484 INFO [bambooAgentMessageListenerConnector-1] [CurrentlyBuildingContainer] Agent 1015940502 finished building MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165, but the build is still processed by the server. Detaching it from the agent
2014-12-17 15:02:52,916 INFO [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [LocalBuildResultProcessor] Processing build result MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165...
2014-12-17 15:02:53,976 INFO [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [LocalBuildResultProcessor] MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165: All post build plugins have finished
2014-12-17 15:02:54,027 INFO [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [PlanStatePersisterImpl] MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165: Generating build results summary...
...
2014-12-17 15:05:04,418 INFO [scheduler_Worker-3] [OrphanedBuildMonitorJob] MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165 marked as InProgress but not present in CBC since Wed Dec 17 14:52:04 UTC 2014
2014-12-17 15:05:04,418 ERROR [scheduler_Worker-3] [OrphanedBuildMonitorJob] Build MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165 had to be cancelled: it was marked as in progress in DB but no agents were assigned to it.
2014-12-17 15:05:04,418 INFO [scheduler_Worker-3] [DefaultErrorHandler] Recording an error: Build MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165 had to be cancelled: it was marked as in progress in DB but no agents were assigned to it. : MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT
2014-12-17 15:06:25,203 INFO [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [TestsManagerImpl] Test migration to BuildResultsSummary complete for MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165
...
2014-12-17 15:06:48,681 INFO [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [PlanStatePersisterImpl] Finished build: MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL20-FUNCUNIT-165
{noformat}

What happened?
* The agent successfully finished the build and send the results to the server
* The server was a bit busy and didn't attend to it immediatly
* After 10 minutes, it finally started to processing them
* The build result generation took longer than expected: normally just a couple of seconds - but not this time. For unknown reasons it took a couple of minutes
* In the mean time, the OrphanedBuildMonitorJob sees this build still hanging around ... and kills it
* Later, the build result is actually succesfully processed

Result: despite the build being successful, the OrphanedBuildMonitorJob marked it as cancelled which means it effectively failed.
fields.summary: OrphanedBuildMonitorJob should not invalidate unprocessed build results

The generateSnapshot.sh script in the EC2 instances no longer works properly 'out of the box'.

{code}
# generateSnapshot.sh

100   430  100   430    0     0   162k      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  209k

File not found: '/root/pk.pem'

The issue appears to be that the AWS_ACCESS_KEY and AWS_SECRET_KEY, or similar, aren't configured - so because it's still set up to use the ec2-api-tools-1.6.13 by default, it falls back on the now-deprecated use of the SOAP certificates (which I no longer upload, as those commands are turned off at the end of the month).

It's easily fixed by configuring the environment variables - but there's no reason the image shouldn't be set up like that to start with.

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo v5.7.2 does not provide the ability of restricting users from editing {{Plan configuration}}.

With Bamboo becoming a deployment tool, it has to run under the service account with the elevated privileges to deploy and install in various environment. Giving developers ability to edit the build plans, open up a security breach that potentially enables them to use that privileged service account to run DOS and PowerShell code. So we need to find a compromise – allow the developers to see how the build is set up, but to not let them modify things there.
fields.summary: Permission to view plan configuration but not edit it

fields.description:
Have some way of seeing the overall status for a project.

Example:
I have project "Human" with plans "Feet", "Knees", "Head", "Walk", and "Talk"
The plans can be triggered automatically or manually and run their tests. If all of them are successful, I want to be able to see a "Human" status of green. On the other hand, if even a single plan is failing as of its last build, I want to see a "Human" status of red.
fields.summary: Project-Level Status

fields.description:
Sometimes, users might want to scp some files from bamboo to a target machine that sits behind SSH proxy server.Effectively using the configuration:

bamboo server -->SSH proxy server --> Target server

Normally the SSH proxy configuration will be set in the {{/<user>/.ssh/config}} file and this will work from the command line with something like:

{code}
scp -P 22 test.txt someuser@target-server:/tmp
{code}

However bamboo will fail in the scp task with connection timeout errors due to the proxy not being applied
fields.summary: SCP task should be able to read the ssh config file for proxy settings

fields.description:
*steps to reproduce*
# Integrate bamboo with LDAP
# Configure the [ldap caching|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+the+caching+of+your+LDAP+repository] so that the cache got refreshed every 20s for example 
# Now create a group and associate a user to it
# The group will be created and the user associated as expected
# Now remove the user from the group and wait for the cache to run

*Expected behaviour*
Bamboo should remove the user from the group as well

*Current behaviour*
The user is still associated to the group and only a restart will remove the group association from the user. This only affects group membership as user details and creation of new groups get updated immediately. It appears this properties " LDAPGroupManagerReadOnly.*.groups_hasMembership and LDAPGroupManagerReadOnly.*.groups_getGroupsForUser" are ignored by the cache.

There is no error in the logs even when the "com.atlassian.user" class is set to DEBUG
fields.summary: Ldap group membership not updated without a restart

fields.description: If I use TextProvider in my Task, and I then install a new version of my plugin which changes the message associated with a key, TextProvider will not see this update until the server is rebooted. It would be good if the plugin could be updated without a reboot (TextProvider would need to maintain context of a key and clear that context when the associated plugin is updated)
fields.summary: TextProvider caches text until reboot

fields.description: Regarding Task API: Currently, for a Bamboo Task configuration, you can only specify a single, static field error message using ErrorCollection. (Others can be added, but are not displayed.) There are some circumstances where you would want to modify the error message based on context. Also, when a plugin is updated, the text of the error message may need to be changed. ErrorCollection should at least expose an API to modify the primary message for a field.
fields.summary: ErrorCollection should allow for changing error message

fields.description: in validate() method of TaskConfigurator, I call ErrorCollection.addError(key, string) to display an error message in the Task configuration GUI. If I later install a new version of my plugin, in which the "string" associated with that "key" has changed, and in the configuration of the task the addError method is again called, the ErrorCollection will still keep the old string asociated with that key rather than replacing it with the new one. A server reboot is required to clear this.
fields.summary: ErrorCollection persists error strings

fields.description:
HI everyone

fields.description:
Hi,

I think it might be really good idea if in bamboo appear variable which will tell about 1st run or rerun. I use rerun engine in order to get less work and I want to run my script every time I made a change but until I get positive results. All is based on maven and trick to do less work is not using "mvn clean" - I want to run it only on 1st run.

variable as: bamboo.firstRun = true / false would be wounderful.

Little change but can be really good improvement in CI process.

I like clean and easy fix. After spent few days I figured it would be the easiest way to achieve fine result without any dirty fix.

Thanks in advance!
fields.summary: Adding variable which define if build is first run of build or rerun

{noformat}

...
Caused by: javax.xml.bind.DataBindingException: javax.xml.bind.UnmarshalException

SEVERE: Context [] startup failed due to previous errors

fields.description:
By adding the "needClientAuth=true" attribute to the bamboo.jms.broker.uri, client certificates are required by the Bamboo server.  However, there seems to be no simple way of setting the activemq SSLContext such that a trustStore can be selected for the broker communication only.

The activemq library used does indeed have the possibility of setting a SSLContext for the broker communication, and one can thereby set the keyStore, trustStore, trustStorePassword, etc, only for the broker, without affecting other communication.  Setting the javax.net.ssl.trustStore on the VM is not a good idea, as it will invalidate the general https-traffic from the Bamboo server to e.g. atlassian (for updates/plugins, etc).

Adding the possibility to set e.g. bamboo.jms.broker.ssl.keyStore, etc., would greatly enhance security by adding the possibility to limit connection only to build agents that hold a trusted certificate.
fields.summary: Client certificate authentication of build agents by setting activemq SSLContext in config

fields.description:
The ability to rollback a release seems to be prevented when an additional artifact is included in a subsequent build of a plan.

Build a plan with Art_x and Art_y. Deploy #1 as rel-A. Realise that we need additional elements in the next version, so add Art_z to the current build and create #2. Release as rel-B. After release we realise there was a bug, and want to rollback to rel-A, but "rollback" will error and indicate that Art_z can't be located. This was not part of the rel-A deployment, but is now part of the latter build.  Workaround is to modify the expected artefacts to allow this to proceed.

An improvement to Bamboo will be to re-deploy based on the artifacts used at the point the original deployment.
fields.summary: Deployment rollback should match only previously deployed artefacts

fields.description:
When I perform an export from Bamboo 5.7.1, I consistently get illegal characters in the file db-export/testCaseResultErrors.xml

This prevents subsequent imports from the same file.

The workaround is to unzip the export file, fix db-export/testCaseResultErrors.xml manually, and then re-zip; however, this can be cumbersome when you have export files of 10GB or more.
fields.summary: Invalid character data in XML export

fields.description:
This issue is resolved for elastic and remote agents using remote artifact handlers. Local agents and agents using other handlers (including S3) do not preserve the permissions.

h3. Reproducing issue:
# create a new Project (i.e.: Support), Plan (i.e.: MyPlan)
# add an "{{Script}}" task
{code}
# creates a new file
touch executable.jar

# list files
ls -l

# change its permission
chmod 755 executable.jar

# list files
ls -l
{code}
As a result you would have something like:
{noformat}
12-Dec-2014 14:08:52	total 0
12-Dec-2014 14:08:52	-rw-r--r--  1 root  root  0 Dec 12 14:08 executable.jar
12-Dec-2014 14:08:52	total 0
12-Dec-2014 14:08:52	-rwxr-xr-x  1 root  root  0 Dec 12 14:08 executable.jar
{noformat}
# create an Artifact definition as per following:
{noformat}
Name: myArtifact
Location:
Copy pattern: executable.jar
[x] Shared
{noformat}
# go to "{{<bamboo-home>/artifacts}}" and run the following:
{code}
ls -l SUP-MYPLAN/shared/build-00001/myArtifact/executable.jar
{code}
As a result you would have something like:
{noformat}
-rw-r--r--  1 root  root  0 Dec 12 14:08 SUP-MYPLAN/shared/build-00001/myArtifact/executable.jar
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
- Write a script job that will re-set the correct permissions
- Tar everything up before creating the artifacts and then pass around a tarball rather than just pure artifacts.
fields.summary: Artifact permissions are not preserved for elastic and remote agents using remote artifact handlers

fields.description:
Bamboo throws errors because seems to rely on existing definitions in a build plan, even when trying to re-deploy an older build. This is a broken feature because I am unable to rollback or redeploy old releases which should have no relationship to the current latest build configuration.

—

In my build plan, I was collecting to sets of artifacts. Let's call them "artfacts1" and "artifacts2". I created a build called "build-1", and these artifacts were archived with that build.

I created a deployment plan, and it referenced both "artifacts1" and "artifacts2". I created a release called "release-1" and deployed them.

Later, I decided to remove "artifacts2" from my build plan because moving forward I don't need them.

Now I realize I need to rollback/redeploy my existing deployment using "release-1". If I try to do this, I get:
"Could not execute 'ENVIRONMENT:6258689': java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Unable to find an artifact definition for name: artifacts2"


I've attached a screenshot as well illustrating the error.
fields.summary: As a Bamboo user I want to Re-Deploy use the same deployment procedure as the original deployment

fields.description:
A customer recently complained that the test reports they so valued had disappeared.  Turns out they are still there, but you need to do a cryptic dance of clicking just the right links in the right order, or you end up on a completely different page!!!


# start at plan overview - /browse/LF-TOOLPROVISIONING
# click tests - /browse/LF-TOOLPROVISIONING/test
!Screen Shot 2014-12-11 at 8.50.17 AM.png|width=400px!
# Click a specific test - /browse/LF-TOOLPROVISIONING-JOB1/test/case/86380749
## Note you are on the "Tests" tab= for a specific job based on the test we clicked
## NOte the Test Summary heading, listing of failures.
## No reports, etc.
# Click either Job Summary or Recent Failures tab - /browse/LF-TOOLPROVISIONING-JOB1/failures
# Click back to the tests tab - /browse/LF-TOOLPROVISIONING-JOB1/test
## note identical URL is now at Job level instead of plan, and shows a completely different page.
!Screen Shot 2014-12-11 at 8.48.14 AM.png|width=400px!



We need to know what the expected way to get to the last URL is directly!  It seems there is no way but this cryptic back and forth that somehow dives from plan level to job level based on the test you choose.

fields.description:
We've tried to rolled back a deployment release to a previous version but Bamboo failed to download the release artifact because the build result had already been cleaned up. I guess the artifacts are still on S3 but Bamboo failed to generate the proper link.

From my understanding, build expiry and deployment artifacts are decoupled and purging the producing build should not impact the deployment of a release.

{noformat}
2014-12-10 05:16:40,178 INFO [http-bio-8085-exec-50] [AccessLogFilter] <user> GET http://intsys-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/build/artifactUrlRedirect.action?planKey=XXX-YYY&buildNumber=111&artifactName=Foo%20Bar 2613074kb
2014-12-10 05:16:40,183 WARN [http-bio-8085-exec-50] [ResultsSummaryAwareInteceptor] Action com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.chains.ArtifactUrlRedirectAction' is resultsSummaryAware but no resultSummary can be found for XXX-YYY-111
2014-12-10 05:16:40,186 ERROR [http-bio-8085-exec-50] [ExceptionMappingInterceptor] null
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.chains.ArtifactUrlRedirectAction.getArtifactLink(ArtifactUrlRedirectAction.java:83)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.chains.ArtifactUrlRedirectAction.execute(ArtifactUrlRedirectAction.java:26)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:57)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:606)
{noformat}

-Applied workaround: turn off expiry of build results (so only expire build artifacts and build logs).-
I'm not aware of a workaround. But we've disabled the expiry of build results on all Bamboo servers so this won't happen for releases created in the past week. It seems for the moment, releases older than our one week expiry period cannot be used for a rollback.

*Clarification:* the problem here is _not_ deployment expiry; it is actually disabled. The problem is that while performing the rollback, the code ({{ArtifactUrlRedirectAction}}) tries to find the build result that created the artifacts in the first place (similar like clicking on one of the artifacts in the screenshot below). But this build result had been expired. So the query fails and the rollback as well. Nevertheless, the deployment artifacts are still existing on S3.

!Screenshot - 231214.png!
fields.summary: Unable to roll back deployment project release due to expired build results

fields.description:
After running specific build types, a restart of the server in which a remote agent had been run is required (i.e. you installed a driver that left the machine in an unclean state thus requiring a restart). Having a restart task would perform the following steps (that currently need to be manually done with the help of [a third-party API|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.edwardawebb.bamboo-agent-apis], [documentation for add-on on this link|https://eddiewebb.atlassian.net/wiki/display/AAFB/Agent%20Apis%20for%20Bamboo]). That's how this task would work:
- At the beginning of the task the Bamboo agent informs the server that a reboot is about to take place, then it reboots the machine.
- Since the server knows the agent will be going offline for the reboot, the job does not fail.
- After the reboot, when the Bamboo agent reconnects to the server, the server proceeds with the next task in the job.
- If the agent has a delay in reconnecting to the server the usual "hung job" timeout logic applies similar to if the job had stopped producing output.
fields.summary: Add a task reboot machine

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce, after having configured an application link between Bamboo and JIRA:
# Go to the Build Result Summary page, "Tests" section.
# In one of the failed tests, click the cog icon to the right and *create* a JIRA issue. 
# After filling in the JIRA issue details:
## In Bamboo side, check that a link to the JIRA issue was created below the test name.
## In JIRA side, check that the issue was created, and that the "Issue Links" section in the JIRA issue contains a text "Created from test" and a link to the test afterwards.

The above is working fine. 

But now, if you:
# Click the cog icon to the right of another failed test and select the option to *link* a JIRA issue
# Type the key of the JIRA issue you've just created:
## In Bamboo side, check that a link to the JIRA issue was created below the test name.
## In JIRA side, check that the JIRA issue *will not* list the test name in the "Issue Links" session.

See screenshots:
!BambooSide.png!
Here we can see the JIRA issue below the two failed tests ({{testAdd}} and {{testMultiply}}). The JIRA issue was created based on {{testAdd}}.

!JiraSide.png!
Here we can see only {{testAdd}} listed in the Issue Links section.
fields.summary: Linking to a JIRA issue from failed tests not fully functional

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce
- Configured application link directly between JIRA and Bamboo
- Added Bamboo Plans gadget in JIRA
- Setup Apache with SSL 
- Removed application link in both JIRA and Bamboo
- Re-created application link to run through proxy with SSL
- Revoked access tokens in Bamboo
- Re-authenticated via gadget in JIRA
- Tokens created in Bamboo still points at old URL(pre proxy configuration)
fields.summary: OAuth access tokens pointed at wrong application URL

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo server can be configured to automatically failover to another server if something goes wrong. Unfortunately the agents don't seem able to handle connecting to a different Bamboo server in an automatic fashion.

If Agents were smart enough to update the Bamboo server connection mid build this may be possible, but right now a build will terminate if Bamboo goes through a failover.
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo to be configured for a failover scenario

fields.description:
Bamboo server retrieves artifacts from agents after builds complete. Since its risky to rely on network transfers, Bamboo saves tmp files that are only removed when full files get to the right locations. The method that does the cleanup treats it as best effort. It goes through the directory and tries to delete each file one by one. If the method fails for any reason it just goes to the next file. 

Please provide better built-in logging and handling for this process. Checking the directory for the files that are not deleted, and having details in the logs help determine the root cause and handle situations when these temps stay on hard drive and consume a lot of space.
fields.summary: Better logging and handling for temp artifact files

fields.description:
The Bamboo build variable page displays the following stack trace error whenever there's the word *password* listed on a Variable Name:

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: In expression [@ww.textfield name=id theme="simple" cssClass="inline-edit-field text long-field" autocomplete="off" value=value /] [id] evaluated as [key_-3310642] was deemed unsafe
fields.summary: Bamboo build variable error

fields.description:
After the weekly release of 8th of December 2014, custom AMI's will fail to start.

This is caused by an older version of the Agent running on the AMI. Elastic Instances will remain pending until the instances is terminated.

One of the following error messages will be shown in the Elastic Agent log on the EC2 instance itself (/home/bamboo/elastic-agent.out)

{noformat}
2014-12-08 08:44:56,082 INFO [main] [ElasticAgentBootstrap] Starting Agent Bootstrap using Java 1.6.0_45 from Sun Microsystems Inc.
2014-12-08 08:44:56,262 INFO [main] [ElasticAgentBootstrap] No tunnelling. Using standard protocol handlers.
2014-12-08 08:44:56,275 INFO [main] [ElasticAgentBootstrap] Starting tunnel server
{noformat}
with the Agent remaining stuck on this message


*Fix*
Install the latest Bamboo Agent ZIP and install it into your AMI and create a new one - can be found here https://maven.atlassian.com/content/repositories/atlassian-public/com/atlassian/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo-elastic-image/3.4/
fields.summary: Elastic Agent won't start on EC2 instances in OnDemand

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Variable value entry in under both {{Plan configuration >> Variables}} and {{Build Run >> Run Customized}}, is currently a text field. The ability to select from a list of values in a dropdown is desired. 


h3. Suggested Solution
The improvement request suggested would be having the same dropdown for the "{{Value}}" field having it associated with the "{{Variable name}}" selected, avoiding the necessity to go back to "{{Bamboo administration >> Build resources >> Global variables}}" to verify the value entered to the variable created.
fields.summary: Variables' value as dropdown list and input field

fields.description: Korean characters are not correctly displayed in live log, even though the underlying build log can be downloaded and displayed correctly at a later point.
fields.summary: Korean Characters not correctly displayed in live log

fields.description:
When visiting the Bamboo Wallboard, we are able to see if a build plan ran successfully or failed.

This view does not allow us to see the result of the stages that make up this build though. So for instance, if a plan includes:
- A test stage
- A release stage
As a Bamboo user I'd like to be able to see that the build failed, but that the test phase was successful (so tests are just fine) but the release phase was the one in failure. So this addition would allow us to see what stage is broken.
fields.summary: As a Bamboo user, I'd like to be able to see the status of stages and not just the build result in the Bamboo Wallboard

fields.description:
When we encounter an issue with an JUnit xml file that may not parse correctly Bamboo we should return the line and position of the error in the UI, not just to the Bamboo logs. 

This improves the end user experience, allowing them to go fix the file, rather than looking through logs.
fields.summary: Report JUnit parsing errors at the UI level

fields.description:
People are presented with the option to "Rebuild" a failed plan. The obvious interpretation of this is that it kicks off the build again. Unsuspecting users are surprised when it deletes the logs of the previous build. That is rarely, if ever, the intention. Is it a vanity thing, a possibility to rewrite the history to make believe that the build never failed?

Please get rid of the rebuild button or at least let us disable it for most/all users.
fields.summary: Rebuild should trigger new build

fields.description:
Plan variable description caused confusion for its syntax. In the description, it is mentioned as below:
bq. ... For inline scripts, variables are exposed as shell environment variables which can be accessed using the syntax $BAMBOO_MY_VARIABLE_NAME (Linux/Mac OS X) ...

However, the syntax is actually *$bamboo_MY_VARIABLE_NAME* which has Bamboo word in all lowercase letters.
fields.summary: Plan variable description caused confusion for its syntax

fields.description:
Scenario: 
- Stash and Bamboo on same machine
- Moved my stash home dir during upgrade, thus moving my repos.
- Updated bamboos repos to reflect new file path.
- Keep getting errors saying that the repo polling trigger can't find the repo, yet it is searching the old directory path

m.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException : java.lang.RuntimeException: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandException: command /usr/bin/git ls-remote /opt/atlassian/stash/data/repositories/22 failed

NEW path is not /opt/atlassian/stash.

Issue persists after removing the polling build trigger and adding again.

*Workaround:*
Restart Bamboo
fields.summary: Polling build trigger continues to use old git repo dir when path has been changed in repo def.

I don't have a problematic agent atm, so just attached a normal one to show the issue. Will update when it happens again

fields.description:
From version 1.6.14.0 onwards of the Amazon EC2 CLI tools, the private key (-K, --private-key) and X.509 certificate (-C, --cert) options are not supported. This means that custom bamboo EC2 instances will shut down within minutes of starting up if they are using those variables.

You may see the following stack trace on your EC2 instance before it is shut down:

{noformat}
==> setupEbsSnapshot.log <==
Unexpected error:
org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault: General security error; nested exception is: 
java.security.cert.CertificateParsingException: invalid DER-encoded certificate data
at org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault.createFault(XFireFault.java:89)
at org.codehaus.xfire.client.Invocation.invoke(Invocation.java:83)
at org.codehaus.xfire.client.Invocation.invoke(Invocation.java:114)

fields.description:
Allow concurrency to be set/modified at a build level such that you can specify certain builds to be waited on. This will allow for multiple workflows through a single Bamboo instance. Agents wouldn't be consumed (dedicated) for a specific build(s) and this would lower the overall time builds with specific requirements would have to wait to be grabbed by an agent.

Use case:
Multiple commits are made in succession and trigger multiple of the same build. If an agent is dedicated then the builds would run in order, but once those builds are done the agent remains unavailable to other builds. If this feature existed builds could not have any agents dedicated, but know not to run if a previous build would be running concurrently.
fields.summary: Allow build concurrency to be set against specific builds

fields.description:
It would be great to have a possibility of stopping running builds using the REST API.

Nowadays it is possible to [delete *enqueued* builds|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Bamboo+REST+Resources#BambooRESTResources-BuildQueueService], but that's different from stopping builds that are already running.

Also, the builds are not hung, so using the [HBK plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.buildeng.hung-build-killer] is not relevant.
fields.summary: REST API to stop running builds

fields.description:
* Maven can run in parallel with the "-T" option
* Bamboo can run multiple jobs in parallel


for a large project involving 100s of modules, I'd like a plugin that would allow me to spread compilation or test across X number of generic jobs.  I'd configured a plan with a maven inspection phase with one job and a maven execution phase with one job-template.  Upon execution the inspection phase would determine what could be run in parallel and generate list of "-pl group:artifact" for each parallel track.

The execution phase would fork off as many job templates as desired and would populate their command line from the results of the maven inspection phase.

my 10hr build would compress to 1 hr and be spread across 10-20 systems.

I figure this may require a maven plugin and a bamboo plugin to accomplish.
fields.summary: Automatically spread maven multi module across parallel jobs

fields.description: It will be nice if triggering a failed job via the custom "Rerun failed/incomplete jobs" ALWAYS trigger the job on the same agent as last built unless the agent is offline.
fields.summary: Rerun of builds should use the same agent used to build originally

fields.description:
The revision selection in the "Run customised build" dialog box works well with SVN as SVN revisions are numbers but trying to remember Git revisions is not very easy.

The revision selection should ideally be a dropdown list with the last 10 / 20 (configurable) revisions retrieved from the repository..
fields.summary: Run customised build - > Revision input is not very easy with Git

fields.description:
Hi,

A user can trigger a normal or a custom build from within the plan page but on the dashboard there is only "run" button available.

This causes issues on custom builds where the "parameters" need to be modified and the user accidentally click on the "run" button.

Unfortunately due to the lack of proper "Parametrized build" support in Bamboo this causes more issues.
fields.summary: Missing "custom build" option on the Dashboard

fields.description:
While Bamboo has several VCS integrations (Git, SVN, etc), there are other version control systems out there that don't currently have integrations with Bamboo, one being [CA Harvest SCM|http://www.ca.com/us/devcenter/ca-harvest-software-change-manager.aspx].

Can you consider supporting this SCM as well?
fields.summary: Compatibility with CA Harvest SCM

fields.description:
Elastic Bamboo Agents currently require signing certificates as they use the SOAP API to manage EC2 resources (such as EBS snapshots).

As per http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-soap-api.html, these SOAP APIs will be turned off at the end of December 2014 - less than a month away.

Before then, the Elastic Bamboo configuration needs to be updated to ask for the AWS Access Key (which it does already) and the AWS Secret Key (which it doesn't), and to stop using the certificates. Also, this will need to be made available in time for customers to update their configuration,
fields.summary: Update EC2 API Tools to use REST API

fields.description:
Bamboo 5.7.1 ships with joda-time 2.3, which predates the [Russian timezones changes|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_in_Russia#2014_zone_boundary_changes] .
Upgrade to joda-time 2.6 to have these included.
fields.summary: Upgrade joda-time to 2.6

fields.description:
When a user with only View Permissions reviews the state of a running build under the Plan Summary page, the "progress bar" will also be presented with a "Stop" button, suggesting that the user should be able to stop this build. 

While the Authenticaiton failure is reported in the logs, this is not obvious to the end user. 

Ideally, to reflect the actual permissions in the UI, hide the stop Button. Otherwise, bring the error to the UI.
fields.summary: Hide Stop button when user does not have permission

fields.description:
If a job has multiple artifacts, and one or more of those artifacts is a shared artifact that fails to publish, then the publishing of any remaining artifacts in that job will be skipped.

For example, say a job has artifacts A, B, and C to be published, and B is a shared artifact. At the end of the job, A is published OK, but then if if B cannot be published (e.g. if the directory can't be found), then the job will finish immediately, and C will not be published.

This is a real pain. Those later artifacts may be crucial to diagnosing the build, but we never get to see them because of the premature termination of the job.

Unpublished shared artifacts should prevent downstream jobs from running, but they should allow all artifacts in the current job to be published.
fields.summary: Artifact publishing terminates prematurely if shared artifact cannot be published
